metadata.title: Tribological behavior of Mg-WC nano-composites at elevated temperature

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent past,Mg andAl based light alloys have received substantial attention in automotive and aerospace sectors because of their good castability, high damping capacity and good strength toweight ratio [1]. Among these light weightmaterials,Mg-based alloys are preferred by automotive industries due to their certain advantages like bettermachinability (50%higher than aluminium), bettermanufacturability and comparatively lower latent heat for fusion. Fastermachinability ofMg yields less power consumption thanAlwhile solidification rate is also higher due to lower latent heat. As a consequence, productivity ofmagnesium components becomes 25 to 50%higher thanAl alloys [2]. But applications ofMg-alloys are not favoured in some certain applications specifically in high temperature applications because of poor strength ofMg alloys at high temperature.Moving parts of IC engines (operating range∼175 °C), engine parts (operating range ∼200 °C), cylinder liners and bearings of aerospace systems are those specific zones where use ofMg-alloys is restricted to avoid sudden seizure of components [3]. Significant research studies are thus focused in improving properties ofMg-based alloys so that the application areas becomewiden. In this regard, several practices like alloying rare earth (RE) elements with existing alloys or reinforcing thermally stable reinforcements (fibres or particles) are becoming popular. Various alloy systems likeMg–Al–Ca,Mg–Al–RE,Mg–Al–Ca–RE,Mg–Al–Si, Mg–Al–Sr,Mg–RE–Zn etc have been already developed by researchers for high temperature specific applications [4]. Zhu et al [5] have fabricatedMg–4Al–2RE (AE42) alloy and evaluated tensile and creep properties at elevated temperature. Powell et al [6] have developed creep resistant high temperature alloys like Mg–5Al–2Ca (AX52) andMg–5Al–2Ca–0.1 Sr (AXJ). Recently,Wang et al [7] have studied slidingwear

characteristics of AZ91D alloy at a temperature range of 25 °C–200 °C and a load range of 12.5–300 N.With increasing load, AZ91D shows amild to severe wear transition after a certain limit. Similarly Zafari et al [8]have studied the tribological characteristics of AZ91Dmagnesium alloy at elevated temperature.Wear behavior of AZ91 andAZ91+3RE alloys has been studied for varying load and temperatures [9].
In the present study, an attempt ismade to evaluate tribological properties ofMg-alloys by reinforcing thermally stable nano-particles and subjecting it to dry sliding at elevated temperatures. AZ31 (Mg–Al–Zn) alloy is chosen here as base alloy because of easy availability, low cost and greater castability [10]. In general, AZ31 alloy shows good prospect asmaterial at ambient temperature but it fails to perform at elevated operating temperatures [11, 12]. Liang et al [11] have studied the slidingwearmap of AZ31 alloy at room temperature and concluded that AZ31 alloy is a good room temperature alloy up to 1.5 m s−1 sliding speed. Das et al [12] have studied themicrostructural evolution during high temperature slidingwear of AZ31 alloy and reported that AZ31 exhibits highwear rates when tested at elevated temperatures. One of the possible reasons behind poor high temperature strength of AZ31 alloy is the presence of interdendritic phaseβ-Mg17Al12 [13]. At temperatures around 150 °C,β-Mg17Al12 is formed in the interdendritic regionwhich has lower thermal stability above that temperature. Thus, under high operating temperatures, surfacefinish and tolerance of components at sliding contact get hampered leading to structural failure [14]. In this regard, Luo [4] suggested the introduction of a secondary phasewithfine dispersion to form stable precipitate so thatβ-Mg17Al12 formation could be suppressed. Accordingly, in this studyWCnano-particles have been chosen as secondary phase for reinforcement inAZ31Mg-alloy. Generally ceramic based reinforcements are used by researchers because of their unique characteristics like high load bearing capacity, higher thermal stability and high hardness etc Additionally tungsten carbide (WC)nano-particles possess good oxidation resistivity at high temperature (up to 600 °C), highmelting point (2870 °C), high hardness (1400HV) and good high temperature strength [15, 16].WCparticles also hold better thermal conductivity and good thermal shock resistivity which helps to provide stability of the composites at high temperature [17].
However selection of fabrication process in case of nano-composites plays an important role as nanoparticles acquire larger surface area with high agglomeration tendency and there are issues related towettability. Recent studies revealed that agglomeration related issues can be successfully overcome by using ultrasonic vibration assisted stir castingmethod [18, 19]. Nie et al [18] have observed uniformdistribution of nano-SiC particles with no significant agglomeration. Similarly, other researchers [19–22] have fabricatedmagnesium nano-composites with the help of ultrasonic vibration. Ultrasonic vibration uses high frequency electrical energy to generatemechanical vibrations. These vibrations createmillions ofmicroscopic bubbles. Those generated bubbles implode and create shockwaves, acoustic streaming and very high temperature (5000 °C) resulting in breakage of the agglomerated clusters [23].
Improvement of high temperaturemechanical properties ofmagnesium alloys, with addition of thermally stable reinforcement is well researched in literature. Hassan et al [24] have studied high temperature tensile behaviour ofMg-1.1Al2O3 nano-composite. They found that fabricated nano-composite retained thermal stability till 150 °Cby changing fracture behaviour frombrittle tomixed ductile. Safari andMahmudi [25] have examined hot hardness,microstructure, creep resistance and high temperature strength ofMg-TiO2 nanocomposites. Labib et al [26] have studied elevated temperaturemechanical properties ofMg–SiC composites where significant improvement inmechanical properties is reported due to presence of SiC particulates. Regarding elevated temperature tribological properties ofMg-composites, Labib et al [27] have studied the tribological behavior ofMg–SiC composites at 25 °C–200 °C temperature range under varying load. At room temperature, change inwear rate isminimal for low load but at higher load composites showbetter wear resistance. At higher temperatures significantly lowerwear rate is found for composites compared to pure magnesium. Researchers are also using self-lubricating particles like graphite to improve the tribological properties ofmatrixmetal [28, 29].
In the present study, ultrasonic cavitation assisted stir casting process is used to fabricateMg-WCnanocomposites. Nano-sized particles are used as reinforcement since it shows better end properties in composites thanmicro-sized particles. It is observed in existing literature that small weight percentage (∼2%) of nanoparticles is sufficient to achieve desired property andmore than 2 wt%of reinforcement phase leads towards agglomeration [15, 22, 23]. Accordingly, themass fraction ofWCnanoparticles is varied from0.5%− 2%byweight. Tribological tests onMg-WCnano-composites have been carried out at a temperature range between 50 °C–250 °C and for a load range between 20 N to 40 N. The objective of the present study is to experimentally evaluate the role of wt%of nano-WC, elevated temperatures and applied load onwear and friction characteristics of composites. Studies involving scanning electronmicroscope (SEM) and energy dispersive x-ray analysis (EDAX) ofwear tracks are performed to observe the transition inwearmechanism for varying temperature.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental details
sections.text:
In order to fabricateMg-MMCs,Mg–3Al–1Zn alloy (commonly known as AZ31) is used as basematrix andWC nano-particles are used as reinforcing phase (grade K510,Hongwu International Group Ltd). Typical composition of AZ31magnesium alloy and details ofWCnano-particles are shown in table 1 and table 2 respectively.
Moltenmagnesiumhas special affinity towards oxygen. Atmolten condition,magnesium reacts with oxygen and forms loose oxide coating at themelt surface. This loose oxide allows oxygen to enter further in themelt and formmore oxides [30]. Thus special care is needed for fabrication ofmagnesiumbasedmaterials through liquid metallurgy process. A specially designed bottompouring type stir casting furnace is used to fabricate the nanocomposites in current study. This furnace also has protective inert gas cover arrangement and vacuumpouring facility to protect themagnesiumbasedmaterials fromoxidation. The pictorial view of the furnace is shown in figure 1. Atfirst, AZ31 ingots aremelted at 750 °C inside the crucible of this resistance furnace under the protective inert gas environment (Argon: SF6=9:1). Argon creates a non-reactive jacket over themelt surface while SF6 (in the formofMgF2) block the pores ofMgO film andmake thewhole systemmore protective against oxidation [30]. At the same time, weighted amount ofWCparticles are placed inside the powder preheating furnace and heated at 300 °C to remove themoisture present in particles. Thermal treatment ofWC nanoparticles are effectively utilized by heating at 300 °C to promotewetting through desorption of gases from particle surfaces.Magnesium easily formsMgOwhich acts as diffusion barrier between the interactive surfaces until the ceramic particles are heated above a threshold temperature. It has been reported in literature [15] that
300 °C is the threshold temperature forWC interface.Whenmetal ingots getmelted,mechanical stirrer is placed inside themelt and stirred at 500 rpm for 8–10 min for creating vortex ofmoltenmetal. Then preheatedWC particles are injected in the vortex at a constant rate.When the particle injection isfinished,mechanical stirrer is stopped and ultrasonic probe is dipped inside themelt. Sonification at 20KHz is continued for another 5 min. Then the preheated die is put into the vacuum arrangement and placed near the bottompouring hole. Vacuum condition of 10−2mbar is generatedwith the help of vacuumpump andmelt is poured through the bottom pouring hole into split-type die. Typical parameter settings used in fabrication are tabulated in table 3.
Metallographic characterization of base alloy and nano-composites are performed by opticalmicroscope (LEICA) and particle distributions of fabricated composites are observedwith the help of scanning electron microscope (JEOL, Japan). Required samples are prepared from cast bars through turning,milling and grinding. Etching of samples are donewith acetic picric solution (10 ml acetic acid, 10 mlH2O, 4 g picric acid and 70 ml ethanol) for 3 s. Chemical compositions of the fabricatedmaterials are studied using high vacuum energy dispersive x-ray analyzer (EDAX, JSM-6360,Hitachi, Japan).
Density of base alloy and as-cast nano-composites aremeasuredwith the help of Archimedes principle considering ASTM (American Society for Testing andMaterials) standard E962-08. Vicker’smicro-hardness tests of fabricated composites are performed inUHLmicro-hardness tester (Model–VMHTMOT, Technische Mikroskopie) considering ASTM standard E384-99. Indentation is created on sample surfaces with the help of a diamond indenter by applying 50 gf load and 10 s dwell time.
A typical pin-on-disc type tribotester (TR-20-M56,DUCOM) is used to study the high temperature tribological behavior of castMg-WCnano-composites. Hardened EN31 (EN=EuropeanNorms) disc (58–62 HRC) is used as counterfacematerial. Counterfacematerial with such high hardness is intentionally chosen to ensure that wearwill occur primarily frompinmaterials.Mg-WCnano-composite pins act as specimens that rub against the rotating EN31 disc (115 mmdia., 8 mm thick). A 15KVA induction heating system containing beryllium-copper coils is used to heat the counter face disc at the time of experiments and a noncontact type pyrometer (measuring range upto 975 °C, accuracy±1 °C) is used to sense the temperature of EN31 disc. A button type load cell is used tomeasure the frictional force during experimentation. Experimental parameters are chosen in such amanner that the effect of process parameters i.e. load, operating temperature could be accurately determined. Tribological tests are conductedwithin a temperature range of 50 °C–250 °C according toASTMG99-05. Cylindrical pins (6 mmdiameter and 30 mmheight) are used for these tests. Experiments are conducted at sliding speed of 0.4 m s−1 and three different loads (20, 30 and 40 N) for a duration of 10 min. Effect of sliding distance onwear and coefficient of frictionwithin the operating range is also studied.Wear rate is calculated bymeasuring themass loss of tested pins by using a highly precise digital weighing balance (ER 182 A, Afcoset). Coefficient of friction is directly obtained on-time during experimentation from the computerized set up.Wearmechanisms at different test conditions are studiedwith the help of SEM micrographs and EDAX spectrumof theworn surface.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization
sections.text:
Optical imagesof fabricatedMg-1WCandMg-2WCnano-composites are shown infigure 2. Theα-Mgphase in the formof coarser dendrites is observed inboth composites. Figures 2(a) and2(b) shows thepresenceof equiaxed grains in the composites. Equiaxed grains are formeddue to recrystallisation effect atmatrix-reinforcement phase.At grain boundaries,β-Mg17Al12 in the formofplate like structure is alsoobserved.Good interfacial bonding is apprehended fromthemicrostructures. Figure 3presents the SEMmicrographs of as-castMg-1WCandMg-2WCcomposites. It is
observed that reinforcedWCnano-particles arehomogeneously distributed throughout the composite by creating compact structureswithout any significant signof agglomeration. It is alsoobserved that typical grain size of composites is qualitatively improvedwith the actionofWCnano-particles. Further the compositions of baseAZ31 magnesiumalloy,Mg-1WCandMg-2WCnano-composites are examinedwith thehelpof EDAXspectrumanalysis andx-raydiffraction analysiswhich are presented infigure 4. InEDAXspectrums, peakofMg,O,Al, Zn,WandCare mainly found.Peaks of EDAXspectrum infigures 4(a)–(c) confirm thebasic compositionof the composites and also show thatwt%ofWincreaseswith the increase in amountof reinforcement phase. But exactweight percentage of WC isnot foundas very small areas of the composites are considered forEDAXanalysis.However the incorporation ofWC inmagnesiumalloy is ensured.XRDpatterns forAZ31,Mg-1WCandMg-2WCnanocomposites are shown infigure 4(d). It is seen thatMgpeaks are found at 2θ=32.16°, 34.58°, 36.04°, 48.14°, 57.77°, 63.54° and72.92°. However, nootherpeaks exceptMgcanbeobservedby JCPDSexaminationof all compositeswhichmaybedue to very lowweight percentage ofWCnano-particles in the composites. But analysis result of ‘Match3’ software shows thepresence ofWCandW2Cat 2θ=36.01° and48.18°.
3.2.Hardness anddensity Contribution ofWCnano-particles as reinforcement inmagnesiumbase alloy isfirst recognised by the hardness values of composites. Inclusion ofWCnano-particles shows phenomenal improvement in hardness values of base alloy. Variation ofmicro-hardness with increasedweight percentage ofWCnano-particles is shown in figure 5. It is observed thatmore amount ofWC reinforcement phase results in highermicro-hardness of composites. Grain size of the base alloy and composites aremeasured by Image J software and it is observed that the grain size of AZ31 is 117.216 μmwhile grain size ofMg-2WCnanocomposite is 1.328 μm. It is obvious from themicro-hardness results that grain-size of composites is decreased continuously due to the grain refining effect ofWCparticulates. Precisely it is seen that typicalmicro-hardness of composite having 2wt%ofWChas improved almost 43% than the base alloy.
Typical density values of base alloy and all four composites are obtained by followingArchimedes’s principle. Density of composites increasesmoderately with increase inwt%ofWCparticulates. Density values of base alloy and four composites (0, 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2 wt%WC) are as follows: 1.745, 1.785, 1.793, 1.807 and
1.818 g/cc. Theoretical density values of base alloy and composites are 1.75, 1.8145, 1.8839, 1.9533 and 2.023 g/ cc respectively. Accordingly, porosity of base alloy and composites are evaluated as 0.29%, 1.62%, 4.82%, 7.48% and 10.12% respectively.
3.3.Wear behavior Wear rate of fabricated composites and base alloy as function of temperature at 20 Nnormal load is shown in figure 6. It is observed that wear rate of base AZ31 alloy increases continuously with varying temperature at a fixed load. On the other handwear rate of composites does not show any noticeable change up to certain temperature after whichwear rate starts to increase drastically. ForMg-0.5WCandMg-1WCcomposites, wear rate does not change significantly up to 100 °Cwhile forMg-1.5WC andMg-2WCcomposites that typical temperature is 200 °C. It is quite evident from figure 6 that all composites have better wear resistance than the base alloy at all operating temperature.Wear resistance of composites increases with increase inwt%ofWC content. Primarily better wear resistance of nano-composites in compare to AZ31 alloy is due to higher hardness of nano-composites as observed infigure 5. This is also compatible withArchard’s wear law [31]. Previously, Labib et al [21] explained the possible reason behind better wear resistance ofmagnesium composites at elevated temperature differently. According to them, the hard thermally stable ceramic particles insidemagnesium matrix trap dislocation causing constrainedmatrix flow,which increases load carrying capacity of the composites and resist plastic deformation ofmatrix phase. In base alloy, secondaryβ-Mg17Al12 present as interdendritic phase (figure 2)which lose its strength at elevated temperature and yields plastic deformation.
Accordingly wear rate of AZ31 base alloy increases continuously with increase in operating temperature which is not followed in case of composites. Current wear rate trend as a function of temperature is compatible with the observationmade by Labib et al [21] forMg–SiC composites. Zafari et al [9] discussed that high temperature hardness of baseMg alloy tends to decrease with increasing temperature which in turn resist formation of stable tribolayer. Accordingly wear resistance of base alloy should decrease andwear rate should increase rapidly. In thisfigure it is apprehended that high temperature hardness does not deteriorate thatmuch in composites resulting better wear resistance. Stable tribo-layer formation at the composite contact surface alsomay play some role behind less increase inwear ratewith respect to increase in temperature.
Wear rates of base alloy and composites as function of operating elevated temperatures at 30 N load are shown infigure 7. Trends infigure 7 are almost similar with trends in figure 6.Wear rate of AZ31 alloy increases rapidly with increase in temperature.Wear rate of composites doesn’t change initially and after some certain temperature it starts to increase rapidly. But unlike figure 6, infigure 7wear rates ofMg-1.5WCandMg-2WC composites increase by following a steeper slope after 200 °C.Additionally, at 200 °C,Mg-0.5WCandMg-1WC composites have already experienced increasing rate of wear with temperature whileMg-1.5WCandMg-2WC composites have experienced steadywear rate up to it. So, some differences inwearmechanism at different composites are apprehended at 200 °Coperating temperature.Hencewear tracks are studied andwear mechanism is tried to identify with the help of SEMandEDAX analysis. Figure 8(a) presents thewear track of Mg-1WCpin tested at 200 °C and 30 N load. Figure 8(a) clearly suggests that delamination is themainwear mechanism and adhesion has just started. Typical sign of propagated crack alongwith heavier delamination is identified. Sign ofmaterial flow is seen in thewear track.Wear track shows sign of ploughingwhich indicates that thermal softening has happened at pin surface. Figure 8(a) also indicates that bulk ofmaterial has removed from the pin surface by creatingworn out cavity. Figure 8(b) shows SEMmicrograph ofworn surface of
Mg-2WCcomposite tested at 30 N load and 200 °C. Figure 8(b) shows the presence of work hardened layer and finer sign ofmaterialflow. Presence of work hardened layer yields that the pin surface is protected by this layer fromdrastic wear. Thus the differences inwear rate betweenMg-1WCandMg-2WCas infigures 6 and 7 can be correlatedwithfigure 8. Figures 9(a) and 9(b) shows the EDAX spectrumofwear track ofMg-1WCandMg2WCnano-composites tested at 30 N load and 200 °C. Figures 9(a) and 9(b) both shows oxygen peak in the EDAX spectrumbut oxygen peak offigure 9(b) ismuch stronger.Hencemore amount of oxidized layer is formed inMg-2WCcontact regime compared toMg-1WC. EDAX spectrum also shows the presence ofWand C. Infigure 9(b), additional presence of Fe yields hardmechanicallymixed layer where counter surface debris get mixedwith oxidized layer and formharder protective coating to resist the penetration of hard asperities into it.
Accordingly,Mg-2WC composite shows less wear compared toMg-1WCcomposite at such experimental condition.
Figure 10 presents the variation of wear rate of AZ31 base alloy and its composites as function of temperature at constant 40 N load.Wear rate does changewith temperature in a similar waywithfigure 6 andfigure 7. The only difference is in higher quantitative values of wear rates than previous figures.With increase in load, rate of formation of oxide layer becomesmild andmajor tearing of oxide layer happens.Hence overall wear rate becomes higherwhen load is increased. But the basic tribo-chemical reactions occurred at contact surfaces becomes unalteredwhich results in similar trend ofwear ratewith temperature. From figures 6, 7 and 9, it is observed that with increase in load, wear rate slopes become steeper. Probable reason for this change is dual effect of high temperature and high load. At high temperature (>150 °C) rapid grain growth leads to decrease in high temperature hardness while at high load stable tribolayer formation gets interrupted [8, 21].
SEMmicrographs ofMg-2WCcomposites wear tracks are presented to examine thewearmechanisms at different operating conditions. SEMmicrographs of wear track ofMg-2WCnano-composites under fixed 40 N load and different temperature (50 °C to 250 °C) are shown infigure 11. Figure 11(a) shows theworn surface tested at 50 °C. It is observed that a number of abrasive grooves parallel to the sliding direction are present with some sign of ploughing. Typical sign of delamination is observedwhich is started due to the cumulative action of
40 N force and 50 °C temperature. Oxidized debris is splattered over theworn surface indicating the presence of oxidized tribolayer on thewear track. Figure 11(b) shows thewear track tested at 100 °C.Comparatively smoother surface having clear sign of ploughing is observed inmicrograph and sign of delamination has increased than in thewear track ofMg-2WCcomposite tested at 50 °C. Smoother surface signifies reduction in abrasive wearmode and also justify the linear change inwear rate of composite between 50 °Cand 100 °C. Figure 11(c) shows higher delamination and presence of typical work hardened tribolayer.Work hardened tribolayer of thewear track protects the pin surface fromdirect contact with the counterface. Hencemajor progression inwear rates is prevented. Initiation of cracks and pits are also observedwhich indicates that adhesive wear alongwith delamination aremainwearmechanism at this experimental condition. Figure 11(d) presents worn surface having plastic flowofmaterial towards sliding direction in the formof rows of furrows. Plasticflowofmaterial signifies that thermal softening happened. Cracks are propagated here and large numbers of pits are evident on theworn surface.Hencemainwearmechanisms in this regime are adhesive wear and thermal softening becomes prominent. Similar trendwas observed by Labib et al [21].Worn out cavitywith deep grooves and ductile fractures are observed infigure 11(e).With increase in temperature, thermal softening has increased and partialmelting is also distinct which leads to rapidwear by tearingmetal surfaces [8]. Severe extrudedmaterials are seen at the edges of pins (Figure 11(f)). Figure 11(e) also shows flowof plastically deformedmaterial and their welding onworn surface. Thus thermal softening andmelting becomemore prominent inMg-2WCcomposites tested at 250 °C resultingmajorwear in the end.
EDAX spectrums ofwear tracks ofMg-2WCnano-composites tested at a constant load of 40 N and different elevated temperatures (50 °C–250 °C) are shown infigure 12. EDAX spectrums are taken from the rectangular zonemarked in correspondingmicrographs and corresponding table is attachedwith the images. Figure 12(a) presents the spectrumof samples tested at 50 °C.Noticeable amount of oxygen is observed in the spectrum which clearly confirms that oxidized tribolayer is formed between the pin surface and counter surface. Other components are C, Al, Si, Zn,Mn andW.With further increase in operating temperature up to 100 °C, stronger oxygen peak is observed and Fe peak becomes prominent which is shown infigure 12(b). Presence of Fe peak suggests that counter surface debris havemixedwith oxidized debris to form amechanicallymixed layer.Hence wear rate of the pin tested at 100 °Cbecomes similar with pin tested at 50 °C. Spectrumof pin tested at 150 °C is shown infigure 12(c). Oxygen percentage is increased significantly and Fe percentage is also increased. Higher amount of oxygen and Fe peaks negates the thermal softening effect of elevated temperature and results in linear change inwear rate with temperature. Similar trend is also seen in literature [8, 21]. Butfigure 12(d) presents that
further increase in temperature (200 °C) resulting reduction of the percentage of oxygenwith no sign of Fe. It indicates that oxide layer gets fractured due to the action of excessive heat generation and severe plastic deformation has occurred in the formof damaged surface. Figure 12(e) shows that at 250 °C elevated temperature oxygen percentage deteriorates into 1.52%. Such low amount of oxygen states that no effective surface oxidation has happened and no significant oxide layer has formed. Due to large plastic deformation oxide layers immediately smeared out and developworn out cavity. As a result, wear rate increased drastically.

sections.heading: 3.4. Friction behavior
sections.text:
Variations in coefficient of friction of castMg-WC composites are shown in figures 13 and 14. Figure 13 shows the friction characteristics ofMg-2WC composites tested at 40 N load and five different temperatures (50 °C, 100 °C, 150 °C, 200 °C and 250 °C). It is observed that coefficient of friction of base alloy as well as nanocompositesmarginally decrease with increase in temperature. Similar trend in coefficient of friction is observed formagnesiumbased alloys and composites previously [21, 32, 33]. This trend could be because of smooth contact surface generated by thermal softening and also due to enhanced plastic deformation of contact surface layer. Figure 14 shows the effect of variation of load on coefficient of friction at 200 °C. It is observed that coefficient of friction is decreasedwith increase in load. But the slope of the curve is different for base alloy and nano-composites. In case of base alloy, this slope is steeper throughout while for composites this slope is divided in two regimes. In between 20 N to 30 N this slope is steeper but for 30 N to 40 N slope becomesmild. This study is in line with the observations of An et al [30]. In lower load regime (20 N–30 N), the nature of slope could be due to the improved contact surface andwork hardened layer but in higher load regime (30N–40 N), nature of slope could be due to the prominence of thermal softening. Thermal softening reduces the friction resistance of the contact surfaces and hard asperities of counter surface can easily penetrate into the pin surface. The deep ploughing like groove present in SEMmicrograph ofMg-2WC sample tested at 30 N load, 200 °C also justify such effect of thermal softening on coefficient of friction (figure 8(b)).
Effect of sliding distance onwear depth and coefficient of friction at 40 N load and 200 °C temperature are shown infigure 15. It is observed that amount of wear in case of composites is lower compared to the base alloy for same sliding distance.Wear value has decreased gradually with increasedwt%ofWCnano-particles. Similar trend has been observed for COF also. Effect of applied load onwear rate of base alloy and composites at 200 °C is shown infigure 16. It is observed that wear rate has increased linearly with increase in applied load. But the slope of curve forMg-2WC is less steeper compared to all othermaterials. Values of wear rate for base alloy and Mg-WCnanocomposites at 20 N load and 200 °C are 5.826×10−10, 3.568×10−10, 3.361×10−10, 2.014×10−10 and 1.462×10−10 Kg N-m−1 respectively. COF of base alloy andMg-WCnanocomposites at 20 N load and 200 °Care 0.3, 0.29, 0.275, 0.263 and 0.256 respectively. Thuswith incorporation of 2 wt%ofWC, wear rate and coefficient of friction ofmagnesium alloy gets reduced by about 75% and 15% respectively at 20 N and 200 °C.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present study, high temperature tribological behavior ofMg-WCnano-composites is studied. Basic characterizations of composites are donewith the help of opticalmicroscope, SEMandEDAX. SEMand optical microscope results of cast composites confirm the distribution of nano-particles. EDAX results confirm the inclusion of nano-particles into base alloy. Continuous improvement in hardness of composites is foundwith increasingweight percentage ofWC. Presence ofWCnano-particles improves thewear resistance of base alloy. Wear resistance is improvedmonotonically with increasing wt%of composites. It is observed that amount of wear and friction in case of composites is lower compared to the base alloy for same sliding distance. At all
applied loads, wear rate ofMg-0.5WCandMg-1WC remains unchanged till 100 °C and then experiences a rapid change. But forMg-1.5WCandMg-2WC,wear rate remains unchanged till 200 °Cat 20 N and 30 N load.While at 40 N load, wear rate ofMg-1.5WCandMg-2WC remains steady till 150 °C and then increases rapidly.Wear mechanisms are studied for all composites with the help of SEMandEDAX. It is seen that at 50 °C, abrasion and delamination are themainwearmechanism. In the temperature range 100 °C–150 °C, delamination and adhesion are themainwearmechanismwhile wearmechanism changes to adhesion and thermal softening in 200 °C–250 °C temperature range. Coefficient of friction decreases with increase in elevated temperature and normal load aswell as with increase in percentage ofWCnano-particles. Typically, with incorporation of 2 wt% ofWC,wear rate and coefficient of friction ofmagnesium alloy gets reduced by about 75% and 15% respectively at 20 N and 200 °C.

metadata.abstractText: The present study evaluates the tribological behavior ofMg-WCnano-composites at elevated temperature.Mg-WCnano-composites with varyingwt%ofWC (0.5%, 1%, 1.5% and 2%) have been prepared using ultrasonic vibration assisted stir castingmethod. Characterizations of composites are performedwith the help of opticalmicroscopy, scanning electronmicroscopy and energy dispersive x-ray patterns. Characterization results confirm the presence of reinforcement phase andmicrostructural integrity of composites.Micro-hardness and density of composites and base alloy are studied. Effects of operating temperature, applied load and sliding distance onwear and friction characteristics of composites are examined in a high temperature tribotester under dry sliding conditions. Operating temperature is varied over a range of 50 °C to 250 °Cwhile applied load is varied from20N to 40N.Micro-hardness results confirm the improvement inmechanical properties of composites in presence ofWC reinforcement.Wear and friction behavior ofmagnesium alloy gets substantially enhancedwithWCnano-particles being incorporated as reinforcement.With incorporation of 2 wt%ofWC,wear rate and coefficient of friction ofmagnesium alloy gets reduced by about 75%and 15% respectively at 20 N and 200 °C. Effects of thermal softening in composites get negated by the presence of harder ceramic phase through formation of some hardened layer at the contact regime.
